title: How many total major hurricanes (Category 3 or higher) will occur in the Atlantic Ocean in the 2021 hurricane season, according to the National Hurricane Center?
preds: Seems pretty safe to forecast 4 at this point.

"Tropical cyclone activity is not expected during the next 48 hours."
https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/
Oops, forgot to change the forecast when I wrote yesterday.

NOAA expects no new tropical cyclones for the next 5 days ( https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/gtwo.php?basin=atlc&fdays=5 ). If there aren't any tropical depressions, they can't become tropical storms; if there aren't any tropical storms, they can't become hurricanes; and if there aren't any hurricanes, they can't reach Category 3.
Post mortem: Think causally, not correlationally.

No tropical activity expected for the next 48 hours (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/).  Assuming this holds there would only be 3 days left in the season (end Nov), so I'm throwing in the towel and joining the crowd at 100% for a total of 4 MHs for 2021.

As we draw closer to the end of the hurricane season, it is looking more and more like we'll stay with 4 major hurricanes for the 2021 season. The NOAA 5 day forecast is not showing any disturbances in the Atlantic. (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/gtwo.php?basin=atlc&fdays=5) Revising my forecast from 85% for 4 major hurricanes, 15% for 5 major hurricanes to 99% for 4 and 1% for 5.

Per NOAA from this morning:
----------------------------------------
Tropical Weather Outlook
NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL
700 AM EST Wed Nov 24 2021 For the North Atlantic...Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico: Tropical cyclone formation is not expected during the next 5 days.
Still quiet so I'm pushing up to 99% in bucket 4.   Weird how the season seemed to end so abruptly
still nothing on the horizon, so lowering further on 5 and increasing on 4.

Updated to reflect 10-day jet stream forecast (reduces formation potential) and <82 degree sea surface temperatures across Caribbean and Atlantic (reduces formation potential). Together these two eliminate formation potential. If we could provide decimals I’d give formation a .3% chance but absent of that, going to zero.
In spite of my comment yesterday, it seems going down by another percentage point is appropriate given that there's no activity on the horizon: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1354941

With 4 in the current season, expect 0.5% chance of another CAT 3 in November.  Based on in last +100 years, 2 Hurricanes (CAT 3) have occurred in Nov. 
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Category_3_Atlantic_hurricanes

Now that I'm down to 5% on another hurricane forming, I'll probably go down a bit more slowly (maybe down 1% every 2.5 days instead of 1% per day). I suspect late-season hurricanes will become more and more common. It would be rare, but not unprecedented for a major hurricane to form this late in the year: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Otto

Projections are no new storms expected for a while.  Atlantic very quiet.  Per one clip I found, since at least 1950, the globe - not just the Atlantic Basin! - had no ‘major’ - Cat. 3 or stronger - hurricanes or typhoons from Sept. 26 through Nov. 10th https://www.wokv.com/weather/talking-tropics-with-mike-nearing-last-half-last-month-hurricane-season/K5XRCHGLQNFB3M2B67NBYBM2VU/  Upping my bets for max of 4 Cat 3+ for the year, with 3 chips left on the 5 bucket for now.
99.[insert decimals]% sure. Expertise on subject of hurricane forecasting: 60%–75%. Interest in subject: 90%.
November, 03 - 21 named storms, 7 hurricanes, 4 major. In pace to 23 / 8 / 4 - 3 weeks to go...

Great discussion thread by @JonathanMann on potential interaction effects on hurricane formation.  I found this article at https://www.mdpi.com/2072-4292/13/10/1932.  Searched for 'simultaneous hurricanes' 'interacting hurricanes' etc on Google Scholar without much luck.  I suspect that formation in a given region is not independent assuming that hurricane formation is driven by thermodynamics and that within a given geographic area there is only so much potential energy available for formation - at a given time.   Not a scintillating insight but it is plausible.  This sounds like a great atmospheric physics question for someone at UC Boulder involved in the annual hurricane forecasts.

Continuing to increase the "4" major storms bucket as time runs down, but keeping an eye on disturbances: https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/gtwo.php?basin=atlc&fdays=2
Meanwhile, if anyone can provide input on the question from my last forecast, it would be greatly appreciated: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1352585

Can anyone provide guidance / suggestions on how independent hurricane formation is? For example, it is possible that one hurricane forms in the Gulf of Mexico and the other in the eastern Atlantic simultaneously, but does a hurricane forming in the Gulf of Mexico crowd out the opportunity for other hurricanes to from in the same region? If I think the odds of a category 3+ hurricane forming are 14% and use a naive independence assumption, that would lead me to estimate the likelihood of  an additional category 3+ hurricanes forming as nearly 2% (14% * 14%). I strongly suspect there is a crowding out effect though, so I'm remaining at 1% for the "6 or more" bin, but I'd be very curious if someone has a better framework for thinking about this.

A bit of a late breaking forecast, but given we have already hit the 4 major hurricanes in the window of 3 to 5 projected by NOAA for 2021 (https://www.noaa.gov/news-release/noaa-predicts-another-active-atlantic-hurricane-season), I would say it is pretty likely that we will not have any additional major hurricanes this late in the season. As well, the Insurance Information Institute projected 4 major hurricanes for the 2021 season (https://www.iii.org/fact-statistic/facts-statistics-hurricanes). However, given that the hurricane activity has been above normal and a La Niña weather pattern has kicked in late in the hurricane season (https://www.weather.gov/media/bou/LaNinaOutlook_Oct21.pdf), there is still potential for another major hurricane in the US before the close of the 2021 hurricane season. We aren't out of the woods just yet!
Nothing of concern on the radar and we're late in the game so moving to the crowd
NOAA is predicting 6-10 with a 7-% certainty. Hurricanes are notoriously a crap shoot.  Way too many variables.

Both 2008 and 1999 had a cat 3 or higher quite late - could happen this year too. However, I am modifying downwards from the probability given 1999 and 2008 both as NOAA has not revised their forecast and also because there are signs the conditions to create storms are not currently in place.

I assume this question lumps in Gulf of Mexico storms into Atlantic numbers like the National Hurricane Center does. With that said… Outside view:
-	Four Atlantic-basin major hurricanes exist for 2021. 
-	61 hurricanes have formed in November since 1861 / .38 per year
-	Four of which have become Category 3 or higher /  .025 per year Base rate = 4.025 (aka 4) Inside view:
-	ENSO neutral conditions persist in Pacific (mitigates potential)
-	Sea surface temperatures are normal to 1C above normal in all regions conducive to formation (increases potential)
-	Sea-level pressures have been above normal in all regions conducive to formation (mitigates potential)
-	No African waves exist on satellite (mitigates potential)
-	NOAA’s tropical outlook, updated in August, suggests 3-5 major hurricanes. We’re already at 4. (mitigates potential) Given the base rate, time to 30 Nov, and number of formation mitigators, 99% potential for 4 and 1% for 5.
Only a few small tropical storms and sub-hurricane activity so far.  Inching up bet for bin 4 and aggregating with crowd.
Asleep at the wheel and just correcting for where I left things for too long.

Ok I am actually thinking it might be quite likely we see something like what happened in 1950 - 2 cat 3s or higher some time into October. Not as likely as just having 1 more which I now think is more likely than I previously thought. Now that I look at past hurricane seasons with 4 cat 3s or higher before today's date, they very often have another storm in October and quite frequently 2 more. That said, I only find 6 previous years with 4 cat3s before today's date, so statistical significance is impossible. But better with some data than none. Maybe there is a physical reason for this, like very warm water temperatures and those persist for some time. I am almost tempted to use these 6  previous seasons to really increase the chance of 5 or 6 but am hesitant to do so as I think NOAAs forecast from August is still quite relevant and takes into account a lot of atmospheric physics.

La Administración Nacional Oceánica y Atmosférica (NOAA por sus siglas en inglés) ha pronosticado que la temporada de huracanes de 2021, que se extiende desde el 1 de junio de 2021 hasta el 30 de noviembre de 2021, estará "por encima de lo normal".  Esta predicción hace relación a un rango de 13 a 20 denominadas "tormentas" (vientos de aprox. 63 km/hr o más) e incluyendo de 3 a 5 grandes huracanes (categoría 3, 4 or 5; con vientos de 180 km/hr o más). A esta predicción que realizó de forma preliminar en Mayo-Junio de este año, le asignó una probabilidad del 70%, siguiendole la temporada cerca de lo normal, pero ligeramente por encima. Así mismo, las últimas estadísticas del mismo organismo informaron que el promedio de grandes huracanes, es decir, una temporada promedio de huracanes, posee 3 grandes huracanes de categoría 3 o superior.  Algunos de los factores que posiblemente influirán serán las mayores temperaturas de la superficie del mar en el oceáno Atlántico en relación al Pacífico (que de hecho es producto de masas de aire cálido que posiblemente podrían provocar huracanes, aunque no necesariamente mayores), vientos tropicales más débiles en este mismo océano, entre otros. Si bien los científicos no esperan una temporada mucho más ocupada respecto de la anterior (donde hubo 4 grandes huracanes), esto no hace alusión necesariamente al número de los huracanes mayores.  Tomando en consideración estos datos y la opinión de los expertos, me aventuro a pronosticar con alta probabilidad (45%) que ocurrirán 4 huracanes mayores (los mismos de la temporada anterior) durante la actual temporada de huracanes en EEUU.

2 Majors to date and the following is from wikipedia (1), "2021 Atlantic Hurricane Season - Mid-season forecast" "On June 16, University of Arizona (UA) updated their forecast for the season, with 19 named storms, six hurricanes, four major hurricanes, and an ACE index of 183 units.[20] On July 6, TSR released their third forecast for the season, slightly increasing their numbers to 20 named storms, 9 hurricanes and 4 major hurricanes. This prediction was largely based on their expectation for a weak La Niña to develop by the third quarter of the year.[21] On July 8, CSU updated their prediction to 20 named storms, 9 hurricanes, and 4 major hurricanes.[22] On August 5, TSR issued their final forecast for the season, lowering their numbers to 18 named storms, 7 hurricanes and 3 major hurricanes.[25]" Link to the TSR final forecast of the season (2) below (to save you a click). 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Atlantic_hurricane_season#Mid-season_forecasts
2. http://tropicalstormrisk.com/docs/TSRATLForecastDec2021.pdf

Seeing nerds discussing that they are shocked to see how many named storms already have formed this time of year compared to other years. Significantly above average much like last year. My only inhibating factors are the low base rate and the relative quietness to 2020. But maybe I have to start considering what the question is asking, that is 2021 relative to baselines or even better relative to itself, not relative to 2020. I am trending my forecast to the upper bins as time and evidence progress.

Using these counts for # of major hurricanes in 2010 - 2020: 5, 4, 1, 0, 2, 2, 4, 6, 2, 3, 7 yields an average of 3.2.  Revising this number down by 40% because we're nearly halfway through hurricane season, a Poisson process with rate = 1.92 produces the following probabilities.

So according to this white paper, NOAA forecasts provide VERY little improvement over just using the most recent 5 year average. So I'm just going to ignore the NOAA forecast and make a statistical judgment.
https://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/167939.pdf September 10th is the middle/peak of the hurricane season, and we've had zero Cat3+ so far. So I'll estimate my expected rate for 2021, as 60% of the average for the 1980-2010 of 2.5 major hurricanes per year. This rate of 2.75 * 0.60 = 1.65 average. Assuming a Poisson process with a rate of 1.65 and a time period of '1', gives the probabilities I entered. I haven't even made an attempt to look for a more recent 2010 and later change in trend yet, because the data isn't readily at hand.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Atlantic_hurricane_season

If we use the last eleven years as a base rate, the probabilities are:
2 or Fewer: 45%,
3: 9%,
4: 18%,
5: 18%
6 or More: 18% Based on the source from @Paul-D, which indicates a forecast of 4 with an average of 3.2 per year.   NOAA has a prediction of a 70% probability of 3 to 5 major hurricanes.  As a result, I will adjust the base rate accordingly.

Logical reasoning: Best bet is NOAA's median prediction of 4 is off. Best bet is we will likely see more than average, which the scientists say and which I assume is 3. Best bet is a number other than 4, which is the least frequent number historically. Best bet is we won't see near-record levels of 6 or 7, which are rare. But I'm unsure since we're approaching the heart of the season. Things will be exponentially "stormier" in late August into September. We have to see and keep comparing to other years. So far it's been quiet. The East Pacific has also been busier than the Atlantic it seems, which could "steal" the energy away from the Atlantic? Is there an inverse correlation between the Atlantic and Pacific activities? I won't stray too far in giving "4" bin some chances because everybody's ranges include that. 5 is pushing it, 3 is too low. 4 seems like a good middleground. But again, be cautious because of its low historical tendency. Keep in mind the base rate favors the lower bins.
Tweaking down due to lack of activity. Typically during heavy season you'd get more hurricanes by now than what has occurred.
The CSU August model predicts 4.  I will hedge evenly over 3-5 for now with low (5%) chance for the outside events.  https://tropical.colostate.edu/Forecast/2021-08.pdf

"Elsa is the first hurricane of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, and its formation comes more than a month before the average August 10 appearance of the season’s first hurricane (the 1991-2020 average date for the first Atlantic hurricane formation was August 14, according to Phil Klotzbach). Elsa is the earliest-appearing hurricane in nine years, since Hurricane Chris formed 700 miles southeast of Newfoundland on June 21, 2012, according to Brian McNoldy (he doesn’t count Hurricane Alex of January 2016, seeing  that anomalous hurricane as a left-over from the 2015 season). Elsa is the earliest hurricane observed in the Caribbean since Hurricane Alma of May 20, 1970."

The forecast is for an average of 4 hurricanes - based on https://www.iii.org/article/hurricane-season-insurance-guide. Assign probabilities based on normal distribution; mu = 4 and std = 1.5

Using data from 1967 on from Wikipedia [1], we get an implied probability of: 2 or fewer: 33/54 = 60%
3: 8/54 = 14%
4: 3/54 = 5%
5: 5/54 = 10%
6+: 5/54 = 10%. Even if we look more recently it doesn't change much, though there is a decrease for 2 or fewer since (and including) 2000. The actual numbers are: 2 or fewer: 9/21 = 43%
3: 3/21 = 14%
4: 3/21 = 14%
5: 2/21 = 9%
6+: 4/21 = 18% To me, this suggests around a 40% chance of 2 or fewer and 60% for more than two. There seems to be no increased likelihood for another of the other categories so I'll split it evenly between them. I'm surprised so many people seem to think there will be (by historical standards) tons of hurricanes this year. Maybe I'm missing something.  Other forecasters have looked official forecasts which suggest a lower probability of 2 and a higher probability of many storms due to El Nino effects that I do not understand too well. I'll incorporate those ideas as well and bring down my forecast for 2 or fewer.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_season#Number_of_tropical_storms_and_hurricanes_per_season

So we had 7 major hurricanes last season during a crazy 2020 year. It marked the fifth-consecutive above average season and the numbers were as follows: 2016 - 4 mh (7 total) (15 storms)
2017 - 6 mh (10 h total) (17 storms)
2018 - 2 mh (8 h total) (15 storms)
2019 - 3 mh (6 h total) (18 storms)
2020 - 7 mh (record tied with 2005) (14 h total) (30 storms) La Nina will increase activity and chances of high numbers with El Nino decreasing the number of storms here. Number of named storms and overall activity has generally outpaced predictions which tells me that the models are not quite accounting for some pieces of data when they're making the predictions of "above average". We can also see that the general (few data points) trend is about 50% of hurricanes become major hurricanes which gives us a better number to use. The correlation with storm number seems to be relatively low. Lots of predictions in the 3-4 range from the experts, which leads me to believe we are likely going to see 3-5 overall with slightly weighted toward 4 and 5. The hit-or-miss nature of this lends itself to a single event changing the numbers. Back in a month to see where we are at. All information gathered from Wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Atlantic_hurricane_season

We can all read that NOAA have predicted between 3 & 5 category 3+ hurricanes in the 2021 hurricane season giving a 70% confidence level. 
Climate change has been seen as a precursor to stronger hurricanes. Warmer ocean water assists the formation of tropical cyclones, by providing a higher level of heat energy, but increased temperatures in the upper atmosphere do not assist such formations.
There is an opinion that storm intensity will increase but storm frequency will either decrease or not change. Studies have shown that the increase in powerful  storms has been balanced by a similar decrease in cat 1 & 2 hurricanes.

I did a quick base rate calculation of how many times the median prediction from NOAA actually comes true. I found that in the past 15 years or so, it happened twice. Most of the time, they overestimate. Most recently though, they have been underestimating. On a related note, NOAA and other experts have published revised season forecasts and they all trended upward.

"Forecasters predict a 60% chance of an above-normal season, a 30% chance of a near-normal season, and a 10% chance of a below-normal season."
"For 2021, [] 3 to 5 major hurricanes (category 3, 4 or 5; with winds of 111 mph or higher) is expected."
https://www.noaa.gov/media-release/noaa-predicts-another-active-atlantic-hurricane-season NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center (CPC) will use 1991-2020 as the new 30-year period of record. The average for major hurricanes (Category 3, 4 or 5) remains unchanged at 3.  For baseline, over the last 30 years: 4 in 30 have 6+ (13%), 4 have 5(13%), 3 have 4 (10%), 4 have 3 (13%), 9 have 2, 4 have 1 (all in the 90's), 2 have 0, so 15 have 2 or fewer (50%) So, now for the bad math... NOAA says there's a 10% chance of it being the bottom 50%... so lets say 5% of being <2 and I'll re-distribute evenly up from there (25%, 20%, 25%, 25% respectively)
30% chance of normal, so 25% x 30% = 8%
60% above normal, so 12%, 16%, and 16% for bins 3,4, and 5 respectively
So I'm now at 57% and will proportionally move all the numbers up (increase each by 75%) and voila, a very rough forecast but... "However, experts do not anticipate the historic level of storm activity seen in 2020" which was 7, so I'm going to shave 20% off the 6+ (from 28% to 22%) and put them in the 4 and 5 options evenly (+3% each).  Seems like a decent start...

As noted below most professional forecasts for 2021 predict an above-average Atlantic season, including "three to five" major hurricanes.

2020 featured a record-tying seven major hurricanes. "Five of the last six storms in the 2020 Atlantic season reached Category 3 or higher..":

"El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) conditions are currently in the neutral phase, with the possibility of the return of La Nina later in the hurricane season. 'ENSO-neutral and La Nina support the conditions associated with the ongoing high-activity era,' said Matthew Rosencrans, lead seasonal hurricane forecaster at NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center. 'Predicted warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures in the tropical Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea, weaker tropical Atlantic trade winds, and an enhanced west African monsoon will likely be factors in this year’s overall activity.' " Sea-surface temperatures in the gulf of Mexico have already crossed 27°C/28°C and thus the critical mark of 26°C for hurrican formation and piling up latent energy. However, so far there's no turbulence in sight before 15 June 2021.
